data.text: Exploding of Hunt Carbon Wheels

So I was browsing Reddit the other night and came across this post about a set of Hunt carbon wheels ‚Äúexploding‚Äù randomly. A lot of people were saying that if it‚Äôs a bad tape job then air can enter the cavity of the rim and possibly cause this during inflation. Has anyone ever heard of this happening? If so, is there a way to tell if the tape job is bad or not? I have a set of Hunts and don‚Äôt want to have something like this happen to me.

This happens in rims that don't have relief holes in the side of the rim, of if the relief holes are too small. I typically won't set up a tubeless wheel that doesn't have those relief holes unless the tubeless system uses a complete plastic insert (like what comes on some Enve wheels). I hope that relief holes become a CPSC requirement and standard for carbon wheels, it's a significant safety issue. Tape is not a permanent fixture. Bad tape or good tape, it will eventually fail, most folks don't know to be diligent in inspecting these things, let alone do most shops.
data.author: Darren Ohl

data.text: So every hole or space around the spoke is what? Basically a relief hole. The manufactures don't know what spoke will be installed on the rim and the spoke profile of a bladed spoke is quite different than a round butted spoke so you're always going to have an air gap....The only "bladder" is the tape and tire created a "tubeless" seal. As far as safety...pressure will only blow the tire off or blow a hole through the tubeless tape LONG before it blows a hole through carbon. The PSI required to blow through carbon is immense! The only thing the relief hole really does is allow water ingress to drain...that's it's main function because if you submerge a tubeless wheel with water, the rim fills up with water....not the tire.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: I call BS. Any air that gets past the tape would escape through the spoke holes. This is a hidden void or stress riser in the carbon layup that finally gave way. Saw the same post, quite a few people with Hunt wheels described similar failures. Supposedly Hunt is purchasing wheels from Chinese manufacturers and reselling them at a markup. Sounds like poor quality control. If you want to avoid this, stick with DT, Mavic, or other manufacturers who assemble their wheels in Europe or the US. This is not meant to say that all Chinese wheels are bad, far from it. Quite a few other commenters had wheels from Light Bicycle that they had no issue with.
data.author: Jeremy Charette

data.text: Yep, HUNT are white-label wheels with fancy marketing. I know this because I buy from some of the same wholesale distributors as they do. But everything I receive is inspected thoroughly when it arrives. There are occasional defects. The key is to catch those defects BEFORE they are put into inventory. This becomes more difficult as volume increases and unfortunately, some wheel companies‚Äô growth has outpaced their QC.
data.author: Mike Leland

data.text: How do you detect voids in the carbon fiber?
data.author: Jeff Lipsman

data.text: Ultrasonic scanning.
data.author: Jeremy Charette

data.text: this is recognized as an issue by enve who make their carbon wheels here in the US. If a bad tape job happens and air can get into the rim it can expand and explode. They released a pressure release valve nut to stop this happening and to let you know you need to properly tape your wheel. It‚Äôs not a Chinese carbon vs US/EU carbon. It is a bad tape job and adding too much air. It takes a lot of air to do this so really it is ignoring the signs that something isn‚Äôt right while inflating and ‚Äúpowering through‚Äù. Boom goes the dynamite.
data.author: Phil Thomas

data.text:
I've seen the ENVE relief nuts, but this is a set of 35s on a gravel bike. The pressure shouldn't ever be that high. And supposedly this happened at normal operating pressures. The idea of high pressures causing rims to explode is a bit of a myth. The root cause is a manufacturing defect or damage to the carbon laminate. Also, the stress on a wheel from air inside the rim chamber would be absolutely nothing compared to the stress imposed by a fully tensioned set of spokes. Most likely this is a poor bond between the bed of the rim (the hoop), and the aero fairing. You can see in this case they delaminated spectacularly. https://youtu.be/rr6w6CETe3Q
Pumping up Carbon Bike Wheels until they EXPLODE
youtube.com
data.author: Jeremy Charette

data.text: That video has nothing to do with what we are talking about. That is a tire exploding on a rim. Not a rim exploding due to air getting into the chamber between the rim bed and cavity. I can tell by other posts you‚Äôre making that you aren‚Äôt listening to the many people that are letting you know that this does in fact happen. Including Enve who are transparent that it can and does happen. Hunt is no different. I‚Äôve seen it happen on Bontrager wheels as well. It is usually home mechanics that install there own tubeless setup and either use a compressor and keep going until it fills the cavity and blows. But I‚Äôll leave it at that and say happy riding and I hope your wheels don‚Äôt explode. ‚úåÔ∏è
data.author: Phil Thomas

data.text: Scanning every wheel made isn‚Äôt practical for consumer goods though. In this case ‚Äúquality control‚Äù doesn‚Äôt mean 100% inspection, but rather tighter controls over the manufacturing process. If parts are made right, post manufacturing inspection isn‚Äôt necessary.

data.author: Marco Crown

data.text: A bad tape job can't make the rim explode...impossible. The area around the spoke allows air to escape no problem...how else would they seal it not knowing what size/type of spoke will be used? The rim tape, rim and sealant are the only parts that hold air...if you have air leaking into the rim....you'll only end up with a flat tire..... Ive been running tubeless since about 2003 and road tubeless for the past 8yrs...I've done nearly every tubeless setup that could be conceived that involved non-tubeless rated rims, non-tubeless tires...both. This could never happen due to air pressure. Carbon is stronger than tires and tubeless tape...by a significant margin.
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: It would have to plug all of them....this assuming it completely filled the rim because it would have to bypass the tape and then fill up the rim to hit the spoke hole and coagulate there....specifically. Not to mention the numerous warning flags that would arise long before it got to that point.....like sealing spewing everywhere, the tire not sealing and if you kept adding air, you'd hear it coming out just like pumping up a tire with a tube with a hole in it... The likelihood would be ridiculously low....
data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: It can happen over the course of time. It does. I‚Äôm very pro tubeless. All my bikes are tubeless. I‚Äôm not saying this is a reason to not go tubeless but pretending like it doesn‚Äôt happen doesn‚Äôt help anyone.

data.text: This was actually the reason specialized and Roval had that year where they said their tubeless rims were not actually tubeless and should be run with latex tubes. Apparently Sagan hit a curb and this somehow allowed air into the rim or something and it exploded. I believe cycling tips did a podcast about it a few months back? I could be remembering it wrong but I think that was the jist.

data.text: yeah but what about the impact of the curb? Hitting a curb will not make the tape fail. And if it did, so what? There is a tiny volume of air in the tire at what? 80 psi? It would just go into the rim like you just doubled the tire size instantly. Pressure would drop. Or that is what common sense would say. Would be curious to read otherwise

data.author: Junji Wiener

data.text: I've seen a number of rims of a number of brands failed like this in pictures. There has been pressure build up inside the rim, which can only be from a poor tape job. Usually the excess pressure will come out of the spoke holes, unless there is a weak spot somewhere else. Like a weak point in the carbon rim.
data.author: Matt Vallins

data.text: I broke a wheel while inflating the tire. The carbon fairing actually separated from the rim due to internal pressure that came from inflating and getting past the tape and couldn‚Äôt get out fast enough. So while many people have pointed out that the spokes won‚Äôt seal the holes, the holes were clearly sealed enough in my case. Also, it may not take much internal pressure to separate the fairing from the rim in the first place. When it let go, it was loud and there were carbon pieces flying around my garage. The failure didn‚Äôt look like the photo.
data.author: Robert Frank

data.author: Josh Kebschull

data.text: I have had lots of leaks in failed tape but the air never leaks out the nipples areas. Spoke holes , etc. it comes out past the valve stem as it‚Äôs the path of least resistance. Once air gets into the rim cavity then there is no sealing mechanism on the presta stem/rim. I doubt that a sudden failure of rim tape could do this as the air cavity of the rim is greater than or equal to the tire volume. Pressure would just go ‚Äòpppfffffttt‚Äô and drop to about nothing then leak out past the stem. I guess if you had a tape leak that was slow enough in releasing pressure and you just kept forcing air into the tire and you pressurized the rim a lotttt‚Ä¶..maybe. I doubt rims are made expecting them to be a pressurized air chamber.

data.author: Brett Jacobson

data.text: Carbon wheels are just not worth the hassle... unless you get paid to race; they really aren't that much of a technological need. They can cost hundreds, or thousands of dollars more than very light alu wheels - while only saving a few hundred grams per wheel at best. As comparison -- a full water bottle is 400-600 grams in weight. Add two of those - and you've more than killed the thousands of dollars of weight savings you bought. Thera are amazing alu wheels sets in the 1400-1500 grm range. What more coule you need for your weekend warrior adventures?
data.author: Burke Culligan

data.text: But you still ride with water bottles regardless, or is your advice to run aluminium rims and just don‚Äôt carry water to get the same weight savings? Either way, the whole water bottle weight comparison is super trite. Static weight inside the main triangle is significantly less impactful on the handling and ride dynamics of a bicycle than rotational weight on the wheels. I ride entirely on alloy rims but someone telling people the things they like are dumb is such a boring, tired part of these posts.
data.author: Erik Jansen

data.text: yep i agree with your general premise. only pointing out that if you are concerned about the physical integrity of carbon as a serious risk to your health when riding hard (topic of the OP)-- consider the motivation for having carbon -- maybe the risk/regard is not a high as its worth, and alu will work close enough for your riding goals. If you're fine with riding carbon - money, weight, integrity aside - go for it. more power to you and the pedals.
data.author: Burke Culligan

data.text: I had this happen with a set of Enve AR4.5s. Luckily I wasn‚Äôt riding it and instead came home to find carbon fiber blown across the garage floor. Failed tape and Enve‚Äôs tight sealing hidden spoke nipples. Enve replaced and rebuilt, but I have seen others post about them not covering the failure. Their fix is the pressure relief valve nut posted here above along with an improved rim tape. Making sure rim tape width is adequate to fully span the interior of the rim and a bit of overlap at the sidewall is my approach with these rims now.
data.author: Brendan McKee

data.text: I sometimes wonder about negative reviews. It is often difficult to even figure what is true and what is false. Now, I am not saying that a tubeless wheel will not ever explode. I am also not saying the story about the exploding Hunt is false. All I am saying is that with the pilferage of lies and half truths on social media, one should not simply assume that Hunt wheels are questionable or unsafe. I have been using hunt on my bikes for a while now and have had no problems. But, again, I may be lying. I may be a Hunt dealer. As for Hunt getting their rims from wheel manufactures. That is not uncommon. I think it would cost effective for Hunt to outsource manufacturing of their wheels. They have the equipment and volume, etc. Outsourcing happens every way from electronics to clothing to makeup.
data.author: Felix Telado

data.text: The amount of uninformed comments is shocking. It is impossible for a carbon rim to explode because of inflation. No spoke hole seals anywhere near enough to allow that. Maybe if you blow 300psi in within a few seconds but otherwise I don't see any chance in a world where normal physics apply. The picture above shows what could be either overinflation of a tire, a failure in the carbon layup or a crash.
data.author: Xaver von Treyer
